GLI - Graph Language Interface
  • API Reference
  • gli module
  • View page source

gli module

GLI - Graph Language Interface High-performance graph manipulation library with Rust backend

class gli.Graph(nodes=None, edges=None, graph_attributes=None, graph_store=None, backend=None)[source]

Bases: object

High-level Graph interface with automatic Rust/Python backend selection

__init__(nodes=None, edges=None, graph_attributes=None, graph_store=None, backend=None)[source]
add_edge(source: str, target: str, **attributes) → str[source]

Add edge with optimized node creation. Returns the edge_id.

add_node(node_id: str = None, **attributes) → str[source]

Add node with optimized checking. Returns the node_id.

batch_filter_edges(**filters) → List[tuple][source]

Efficiently filter edges by attributes using batch operations.

Parameters:

**filters Attribute key-value pairs to filter by

Returns:

List of (source, target) tuples for edges matching all filters

batch_filter_nodes(**filters) → List[str][source]

Efficiently filter nodes by attributes using batch operations.

Parameters:

**filters Attribute key-value pairs to filter by

Returns:

List of node IDs matching all filters

Example

# Find all people over 25 in Chicago node_ids = g.batch_filter_nodes(age=25, city=Chicago)

batch_get_node_attributes(node_ids: List[str]) → List[Dict[str, Any]][source]

Efficiently get attributes for multiple nodes in one operation.

Parameters:

node_ids List of node IDs

Returns:

List of attribute dictionaries (empty dict if node not found)

batch_operations()[source]

Context manager for efficient batch operations

batch_set_edge_attributes(edge_attributes: Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]) → Graph[source]

Efficiently set attributes for multiple edges in one operation.

Parameters:

edge_attributes Dict mapping edge_id -> {attribute_key: value}

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Example

g.batch_set_edge_attributes({

alice->bob: {weight: 0.8, type: friend}, bob->charlie: {weight: 0.6, type: colleague}

})

batch_set_node_attributes(node_attributes: Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]) → Graph[source]

Efficiently set attributes for multiple nodes in one operation.

Parameters:

node_attributes Dict mapping node_id -> {attribute_key: value}

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Example

g.batch_set_node_attributes({

alice: {age: 31, status: active}, bob: {age: 26, status: inactive}

})

batch_update_node_attributes(node_updates: Dict[str, Callable[[Dict], Dict]]) → Graph[source]

Update node attributes using functions for complex transformations.

Parameters:

node_updates Dict mapping node_id -> update_function

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Example

g.batch_update_node_attributes({

alice: lambda attrs: {**attrs, age: attrs[age] + 1}, bob: lambda attrs: {**attrs, score: attrs.get(score, 0) * 1.1}

})

create_subgraph(node_filter: Callable[[Node], bool] = None, edge_filter: Callable[[Edge], bool] = None, node_ids: set = None, include_edges: bool = True) → Graph[source]

Create a subgraph based on filters or node IDs

create_subgraph_fast(node_ids: List[str] = None, **attribute_filters) → Graph[source]

Create a subgraph using optimized batch operations.

Parameters:

  • node_ids Specific node IDs to include

  • **attribute_filters Filter nodes by attributes

Returns:

New Graph instance containing the filtered subgraph

edge_count() → int[source]

Get the number of edges in the graph

property edges

Get edges view

classmethod empty(graph_store=None, backend=None)[source]

Create empty graph

classmethod from_edge_list(edges: List[tuple], node_attrs: Dict[str, List[Any]] = None, edge_attrs: Dict[str, List[Any]] = None, graph_store=None, backend=None)[source]

Create graph from edge list (NetworkX-style)

classmethod from_node_list(node_ids: List[str], node_attrs: Dict[str, List[Any]] = None, graph_store=None, backend=None)[source]

Create graph from vectorized node data (NumPy-style)

get_connected_component(start_node_id: str) → Graph[source]

Get connected component containing the specified node

get_edge(edge_id: str) → Edge[source]

Get edge by ID

get_k_hop_neighborhood(start_node: str, k: int = 1) → List[str][source]

Get all nodes within k hops of the start node.

Parameters:

  • start_node Starting node ID

  • k Number of hops (default 1)

Returns:

List of node IDs within k hops

get_neighbors(node_id: str) → List[str][source]

Get neighbors of a node

get_node(node_id: str) → Node[source]

Get node by ID

get_node_ids() → List[str][source]

Get all node IDs in the graph

get_performance_stats() → Dict[str, Any][source]

Get performance statistics for the graph

node_count() → int[source]

Get the number of nodes in the graph

property nodes

Get nodes view

optimized_query(query_type: str, **params) → Any[source]

Execute optimized queries using the best available backend method.

Parameters:

  • query_type Type of query (filter_nodes, filter_edges, subgraph, k_hop, batch_attrs)

  • **params Query-specific parameters

Returns:

Query results

set_edge_attribute(edge_id: str, key: str, value: Any) → Graph[source]

Set an edge attribute

set_node_attribute(node_id: str, key: str, value: Any) → Graph[source]

Set a node attribute

snapshot() → Graph[source]

Create optimized snapshot

class gli.GraphStore(use_rust=None, max_auto_states: int = 10)[source]

Bases: object

High-performance Graph Store with Rust backend support

__init__(use_rust=None, max_auto_states: int = 10)[source]
commit(message: str = '') → str[source]

Explicitly commit current state

create_branch(branch_name: str, from_hash: str = None, description: str = '') → str[source]

Create a new branch

get_current_graph() → Graph[source]

Get current graph state

get_storage_stats() → Dict[str, Any][source]

Get statistics about storage usage

list_branches() → List[Dict[str, Any]][source]

List all branches with metadata

switch_branch(branch_name: str) → Graph[source]

Switch to specified branch

update_graph(new_graph: Graph, operation: str = 'update') → str[source]

Update current graph state

gli.create_random_graph(n_nodes: int = 10, edge_probability: float = 0.3, use_rust: bool = None) → Graph[source]

Create a random graph efficiently using vectorized operations

gli.get_available_backends()[source]

Get list of available backends.

gli.get_current_backend()[source]

Get the currently selected backend.

gli.set_backend(backend)[source]

Set the backend to use for new Graph instances.

Module Contents

The main GLI module provides the primary interface for graph operations.

Classes

Graph

High-level Graph interface with automatic Rust/Python backend selection

GraphStore

High-performance Graph Store with Rust backend support

Functions

create_random_graph

Create a random graph efficiently using vectorized operations

get_available_backends

Get list of available backends.

set_backend

Set the backend to use for new Graph instances.

get_current_backend

Get the currently selected backend.

Constants

gli.__version__ = "0.2.0"

str(object=) -> str str(bytes_or_buffer[, encoding[, errors]]) -> str

Create a new string object from the given object. If encoding or errors is specified, then the object must expose a data buffer that will be decoded using the given encoding and error handler. Otherwise, returns the result of object.__str__() (if defined) or repr(object). encoding defaults to utf-8. errors defaults to strict.

gli.RUST_BACKEND_AVAILABLE = True/False

Returns True when the argument is true, False otherwise. The builtins True and False are the only two instances of the class bool. The class bool is a subclass of the class int, and cannot be subclassed.

Backend Management

GLI supports multiple computational backends:

gli.get_available_backends()[source]

Get list of available backends.

gli.set_backend(backend)[source]

Set the backend to use for new Graph instances.

gli.get_current_backend()[source]

Get the currently selected backend.

gli.RUST_BACKEND_AVAILABLE = True

Returns True when the argument is true, False otherwise. The builtins True and False are the only two instances of the class bool. The class bool is a subclass of the class int, and cannot be subclassed.
